docs.lead_paragraph: Thirteen people have pleaded guilty as part of an ongoing investigation of the state’s home health care industry, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced yesterday. The 13 — a Medicaid recipient, 10 health aides and 2 nurses — have pleaded guilty to a variety of charges in Brooklyn, Mr. Cuomo said. He said some of the aides had false certifications and lacked proper training and some billed for hours they had not worked. The nurses pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges for false billing, Mr. Cuomo said, while the recipient admitted splitting her payments with a home health aide who provided no services. Each month, more than 80,000 New Yorkers receive some sort of Medicaid-financed home health services.

docs.lead_paragraph: Following is the third set of responses from Jerilou Hammett and Kingsley Hammett, the editors of "The Suburbanization of New York" (Princeton Architectural Press, 2007). The book is a collection of 14 essays about the economic and social changes that have swept the city over the past two decades and the Hammetts, who are husband and wife, run DESIGNER/builder magazine. They are taking questions from City Room readers this week. A first set of answers was posted on Monday and a second set on Tuesday. Readers are invited to submit additional questions here.

headline.main: Answers From the 'Suburbanization of New York' Editors, Part 3

docs.abstract: A third set of answers from Jerilou Hammett and Kingsley Hammett, the editors of "The Suburbanization of New York," who are taking questions from readers this week.
